title: Erdős Problem #451: Primes in (k, 2k) Avoiding Products
description: Estimate n_k, the smallest n > 2k such that (n-1)(n-2)⋯(n-k) has no prime factor in (k, 2k). Conjectured superpolynomial but sub-exponential.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham studied n_k, the smallest n > 2k such that the descending product (n-1)⋯(n-k) avoids all primes in (k,2k). They proved n_k > k^{1+c} and conjectured superpolynomial growth. Adenwalla gave the upper bound n_k ≤ ∏_{k<p<2k} p = e^{O(k)}. The exact growth rate remains open.
overview.problemStatement: Estimate n_k. Is n_k > k^d for every d? Is n_k < e^{o(k)}?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines the descending product, Bertrand-range primes, and the avoidance condition. n_k is axiomatised with minimality. Known lower and upper bounds are stated, along with both conjectures.
keyInsights: By Bertrand's postulate, primes in (k,2k) always exist, so avoidance is non-trivial
Erdős–Graham: n_k > k^{1+c} for some c > 0
Adenwalla: n_k ≤ ∏_{k<p<2k} p = e^{O(k)} (product of Bertrand primes)

sections.title: Product and Prime Avoidance
sections.summary: Descending product (n-1)⋯(n-k), Bertrand-range primes, and avoidance condition.

sections.title: The Function n_k
sections.summary: n_k axiomatised as the minimal n > 2k avoiding Bertrand-range prime factors.

sections.title: Known Bounds
sections.summary: Erdős–Graham lower bound k^{1+c} and Adenwalla upper bound e^{O(k)}.

sections.title: Main Conjectures
sections.summary: Superpolynomial growth (n_k > k^d for all d) and sub-exponential growth (n_k < e^{o(k)}).

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 451, asking for the growth rate of n_k — the smallest integer avoiding Bertrand-range prime factors in its descending product.
conclusion.implications: Determining the growth of n_k would illuminate the distribution of primes dividing products of consecutive integers and the multiplicative structure of shifted integers.
openQuestions: What is the exact order of growth?
Can the Erdős–Graham lower bound exponent 1+c be improved?
